summary: Spider-man is a friend of mine, Part 1. Please give me feedback even if it's just correcting my spelling/grammar please ♥️🧡💛💚💙💜
title: Spider-man is a friend of mine, Part 1. Please give me feedback even if it's just correcting my spelling/grammar please ♥️🧡💛💚💙💜
body:
Pairing: Spider-man x reader. Reader as whichever gender you want, I wrote it neutrally so no-one is left out!

Summary: Spider-man interrupts the reader playing the ukulele one warm summer evening. A fluffy scenario ensues where reader shows him how to play, they talk a little. #1K words

TW: Peter mentions uncle Ben. This is mostly fluff but I have left it wide open to be continued, so if you like this I can write more!

I take requests, i’ll write anything with Peter as long as I’m writing for Adult!Peter, because I am a grown-ass woman and I am not comfortable writing under-aged smut :(

You climbed out onto the fire escape gingerly, trying to stay quiet so as not to wake your room-mate up. The cold night air raised goose bumps on your skin, but you welcomed it, breathing it in.


You slowly pulled your ukulele out the window before you shut it quietly. Leaning back against the fire escape stairs, you pressed the instrument against you, strumming it softly. You plucked a few notes, humming to yourself.

You were just playing the last chord of Can’t Help Falling in Love when you heard a clang above you, which made you drop your instrument in surprise. A white blur shot past your eyes and you looked up to see Spider-man suspended above the fire escape, his hand stretched out as a long string connected his wrist to your ukulele. He pulled the string towards him as he landed gently in front of you. ‘Oh I’m so sorry I made you jump and drop this, I was just up on your roof and I heard you playing and I wanted to see and I hope that’s okay, I really wasn’t trying to scare you or anything and yeah…. here you go,’ he mumbled all at once, while rubbing the back of his neck. 

‘Oh no, it’s okay, I’m so clumsy, it’s not you,’ you said, giving him a smile. You couldn’t believe it was really him, a real-life superhero who was actually talking to you and was so close that you could reach out and touch him. ‘Yeah so um, my Uncle Ben really liked that song and it just made me think about him, that’s why I was listening, I promise I wasn’t being creepy or anything’. He was endearingly bashful, and you wanted to keep talking to him. You thought quickly, took a step closer to him and said ‘It’s alright, I know you weren’t being creepy. Do you play?’

‘Oh no, I’m not very good with music,’ he said, his masked eyes narrowed and you knew he was smiling underneath. ‘Do you want to learn a little bit?’ you looked up at him, offering him your ukulele with a smile and trying to sound encouraging. ‘It’s really easy, you’ll see!’ He grabbed the small instrument from you, turning it over and holding it gingerly. He held it away from his chest, supporting it at the base. ‘Like this?’ ‘No, you need it hold it closer. You hold its weight with your right arm but make sure you can still move your wrist to strum it.’ Spider-man held your ukulele pressed against his chest, the right way. ‘Right, now you put your fingers there like this,’ you said, trying to mimic the shape for the E minor chord in mid-air. ‘Can I move your fingers?’ you looked up at him, hoping that he would let you show him. ‘Yeah, please,’ he laughed a little, ‘I don’t know what I’m doing’. You stepped closer, then used your right hand to press his index, middle and ring finger against the bottom three strings. 

‘That’s called E minor, and you play it as you sing the first bit of the chorus, like a river ’. He looked down as he strummed the strings gently. ‘That’s great,’ you said to encourage him, ‘and the next one is a little easier, you just do this.’ You moved his fingers again, this time forming the chord for B7. ‘Strum it when you sing the next word.’ He fumbled a little as he played the previous chord and then the next one, repeating the two. You sang the first two lines quietly, to help him know when to change chords. ‘See! You can totally play if you learn! Maybe i’ll catch you playing that Spider-Pig song,’ you joked. It worked and he laughed, and you felt a little thrill because of it. 

He held the ukulele out to you, ‘thanks, uh, what’s your name?’ ‘Y/N,’ you replied softly, looking at his masked face. ‘Thanks, y/n.’ ‘So, I know you have to keep a secret identity and everything, and that’s why you wear this and everything,’ you said, gesturing to him, ‘but can I know your first name? Feels kinda weird just calling you Spider-man?’ you rubbed your arm a little awkwardly. You were sure that he would say he couldn’t risk it, or maybe he’d just say goodbye and leave now. ‘I’ll tell you if you pinky-promise not to tell anyone else’. He held out his little finger and waved it in front of your face.

‘I do, I pinky-promise I won’t tell’. You grabbed his little finger with yours, squeezing it slightly. ‘Okay. My real name is Peter,’ he said, letting go. ‘Well, it’s nice meeting you Peter’. ‘I have to go now, but maybe you can teach me the rest of that song some other time,’ said Peter, sounding hopeful. You smiled up at him, ‘Yes of course, you know where to find me’.

‘Okay then, I might drop by sometime…’ Peter jumped up on the edge of the fire escape, slinging his webbing across the alley. ‘See you around, Peter’. You watched him as he jumped off, and made his way to the main street, wondering if he would indeed stop by. Either way, it wasn’t every day that you could say you taught a superhero how to play the ukulele. You smiled to yourself as you clambered back in quietly, propping your ukulele up and flopping down on your bed.

Summary: Spider-man interrupts the reader playing the ukulele one warm summer evening. A fluffy scenario ensues where reader shows him how to play, they talk a little. #1K words

TW: Peter mentions uncle Ben. This is mostly fluff but I have left it wide open to be continued, so if you like this I can write more!

I take requests, i’ll write anything with Peter as long as I’m writing for Adult!Peter, because I am a grown-ass woman and I am not comfortable writing under-aged smut :(

summary: How Spider-Man Gets Multiple Suits in Far From Home
title: How Spider-Man Gets Multiple Suits in Far From Home
excerpt: We finally know how Peter Parker will create multiple suits in Spider-Man: Far From Home.
description:
While there’s plenty we still don’t know about the plot of Spider-Man: Far From Home, the trailers and TV spots have already revealed some interesting details, namely Mysterio’s surprising claim that he’s from another dimension. However, we’ve also seen that Peter Parker will suit up in (at least) three different costumes. Going into the film, one of the big questions is how Peter finds the time and resources to create these suits, seeing as how he’s busy traveling Europe, and battling Elementals.

A new international TV spot provides the answer: highly advanced Stark tech, of course!

RELATED:Mysterio Coaches Spider-Man Through His Loss In Far From Home TV Spot

In previous promos for Spider-Man: Far From Home trailers, we glimpsed Tom Holland’s wall-crawler toying with holographic designs for his suits in what appeared to be a workshop. That suggested the young hero was being positioned as the next Iron Man, following Tony Stark’s sacrifice in Avengers: Endgame. However, that’s only the beginning.

The latest promo indicates that Peter’s workshop is inside a Stark Industries jet. We see holographic designs for additional suits, one of which looks to be an upgraded, and comics-accurate, Iron Spider. But the suit is actually constructed using something new: a highly advanced 3D printer. With this machine, Peter’s new suit is presumably complete, and ready for action, within a matter of minutes.

RELATED:Spider-Man: Far From Home’s Stealth Suit Brings Peter Back To Basics

It’s actually a pretty ingenious way to include numerous Spider-Man costumes in a single film, and to boost the sales of merchandise. However, it also has the potential to provide comic book fans with even more nods to the source material.

At the same time, it also makes a lot of sense on a story level. After all, as Peter travels across Europe, moving from one Elemental creature to the next, he can now use his intellect and Stark tech to create suits tailored to specific battles or scenarios. There’s a water monster on the loose? How about a waterproof suit. What’s that, a fire creature is rampaging through the streets? Maybe something a little more flame-retardant, then. In short, now Peter Parker can be ready for virtually anything.

It also ties into the themes of Spider-Man: Far From Home. Peter is trying to live up to the legacy of Iron Man, and the best way to do that is to build multiple suits to help save people – just like Tony Stark did.

Opening July 2, director Jon Watts’ Spider-Man: Far From Home stars Tom Holland, Samuel L. Jackson, Zendaya, Cobie Smulders, Jon Favreau, JB Smoove, Jacob Batalon and Martin Starr, with Marisa Tomei and Jake Gyllenhaal.

reblog.comment:
While there’s plenty we still don’t know about the plot of Spider-Man: Far From Home, the trailers and TV spots have already revealed some interesting details, namely Mysterio’s surprising claim that he’s from another dimension. However, we’ve also seen that Peter Parker will suit up in (at least) three different costumes. Going into the film, one of the big questions is how Peter finds the time and resources to create these suits, seeing as how he’s busy traveling Europe, and battling Elementals.

A new international TV spot provides the answer: highly advanced Stark tech, of course!

RELATED:Mysterio Coaches Spider-Man Through His Loss In Far From Home TV Spot

In previous promos for Spider-Man: Far From Home trailers, we glimpsed Tom Holland’s wall-crawler toying with holographic designs for his suits in what appeared to be a workshop. That suggested the young hero was being positioned as the next Iron Man, following Tony Stark’s sacrifice in Avengers: Endgame. However, that’s only the beginning.

The latest promo indicates that Peter’s workshop is inside a Stark Industries jet. We see holographic designs for additional suits, one of which looks to be an upgraded, and comics-accurate, Iron Spider. But the suit is actually constructed using something new: a highly advanced 3D printer. With this machine, Peter’s new suit is presumably complete, and ready for action, within a matter of minutes.

RELATED:Spider-Man: Far From Home’s Stealth Suit Brings Peter Back To Basics

It’s actually a pretty ingenious way to include numerous Spider-Man costumes in a single film, and to boost the sales of merchandise. However, it also has the potential to provide comic book fans with even more nods to the source material.

At the same time, it also makes a lot of sense on a story level. After all, as Peter travels across Europe, moving from one Elemental creature to the next, he can now use his intellect and Stark tech to create suits tailored to specific battles or scenarios. It also ties into the themes of Spider-Man: Far From Home. Peter is trying to live up to the legacy of Iron Man, and the best way to do that is to build multiple suits to help save people – just like Tony Stark did.

main: @myrxellabaratheon

body:
I just realized a thing!

Flash in one of the Far From Home trailers says that Mysterio looks like Iron Man and Thor, and, I mean… who are the two Avengers Peter always mentions and who he totally adores(d): Tony, his mentor, father figure and friend, and Thor!

So, Mysterio, hear me out: I don’t care how hot you might look in a cape, you hurt my baby spider and I’ll personally hunt you down!

summary: so one of the weirdest things about the snap is that snapped seven-five and under year olds and kids born post-snap are going to...
body: so one of the weirdest things about the snap is that snapped seven-five and under year olds and kids born post-snap are going to have two completely different life experiences. the five year olds who were born post-snap or like. were babies when the snap happened are going to have completely different life experiences than the kids who come back after the snap. they’re only going to remember the world after it was snapped, the hopelessness, just… all the shittiness. and the kids who were snapped are obviously going to be confused when they come back, but they’re not going to have the same life experiences at all as the kids their age because they grew up in essentially two different worlds.
